result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Jeffrey Scott Haller was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.dispoDesc:
Ct #1 amended to 1st degree reckless injury 948.23(1)(6), Ct #2 Aggravated battery 940.19(5).      DEF acknowledges receipt of Information and is advised of rights.    DE advised of rights and penalties; DE waives rights; parties stipulate to facts
DEF pleads No Contest and Not Guilty by reason of Mental Disease or Defect to the Amended charges. 
DEF Found Guilty, but NGI, Not Guilty due to mental disease or defect, Finds clear and convincing evidence that releasing DEF would pose a significant risk to himself and others.
Court finds DEF competent to make his own decisions about psychotropic medication, but advises him to follow his treatment plan.
Court Orders DEF to Mendota Mental Health Institute, Sheriff ordered to transport DEF to facility. Period of commitment 25 years, 15 years on Ct 1 plus 10 years on Ct #2.  Credit for 169 days of time served to be applied to commitment period.  
Return bond to poster.
judgments.action: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

Jeffrey Haller called - sworn by Deputy Clerk - examined Atty Biller.  Cross examined Atty Poquette.   Court questions witness.  Atty Biller makes arguement.  Court questions Atty Biller. APPEARANCES:  Defendant Jeffrey Scott Haller in court via video means with Attorney Martin Jarvis.  Defendant Jeffrey Scott Haller in custody.  Bruce R. Poquette appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

DE agrees with report of doctor that he is incompetent to stand trial at this time.

State agrees to let court rely on facts in competency evaluation.

Court finds DE not competent to proceed at this time, but is likely to become competent within statutory time limits (12 months).  Involuntary treatment and medication is needed, DE not competent to refuse medication for reasons given in doctor's report.  Court suspends proceedings and commits to Department of Health Services for a time, not to exceed 12 months.  DE is entitled to 60 days.
